title: PROOF: The Affirmative Action Committee's Formation Was a Foundational Breach of the 2020 DNC MOU
stakes: West Virginia's minority communities were disenfranchised at the moment the committee meant to empower them was created.
thesis: By installing pre-selected leadership before forming the caucuses required by the 2020 MOU, the WVDP created an illegitimate committee in a foundational breach of the agreement.

axioms.text: Selina Vickers was the lead Challenger whose complaint triggered the 2020 MOU.
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC

axioms.text: The MOU required the AAC be formed with members 'selected by their particular caucus.'
The MOU mandated the State Party 'fully implement... the creation of any new... caucuses.'
The MOU required the process be conducted 'under the supervision... of representatives of the RBC.'
Only the African American caucus existed when AAC formation began in June 2021.

rule_summary: The DNC MOU establishes a 'caucus-first' mandate: legally constituted caucuses must first exist, and only then do they gain the exclusive power to 'select' their representatives. The DNC Rules & Bylaws Committee (RBC) is required to supervise this entire process to ensure compliance.

case_facts.text: On June 2, 2021, Selina Vickers circulated a script for the AAC formation meeting marked 'do not share.'
The script explicitly acknowledged the committee was 'missing... Latino's, Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders, and Native Americans.'
The script pre-selected a slate of leaders before three of the four mandated caucuses could be formed or participate.
The script orchestrated Vickers' own appointment as the committee's Parliamentarian.

logic_chain: The governing rule (the DNC MOU) required an open, caucus-driven selection process supervised by the RBC.
Instead, the factual record shows the WVDP executed a secret script to install a pre-determined leadership slate.
The script itself proves organizers knew that 75% of the legally required racial caucuses did not yet exist.
By proceeding, leadership intentionally excluded these minority groups from selecting their own representatives, violating the 'caucus-first' mandate.
The DNC RBC failed its supervisory duty by allowing this illegitimate process to occur.
Conclusion: The AAC was born from a rigged process that violated the clear terms of the MOU, rendering it illegitimate from its inception.
violation: The WVDP and DNC RBC violated the MOU's 'caucus-first mandate' by creating a committee through a secret, pre-scripted process that knowingly excluded required minority groups. This foundational breach rendered the AAC illegitimate from inception.

title: PROOF: WVDP Failed to Properly Implement DNC-Mandated Diversity Plan
stakes: The failure to form caucuses denied three minority communities their fundamental right under the MOU to select their own leadership.
thesis: The WVDP's failure to establish three of the four required minority caucuses before installing AAC leadership constituted a material breach of the DNC-mandated diversity plan.

axioms.text: The 2020 MOU's primary purpose was to 'establish new... diversity caucuses.'
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC, p. 1

axioms.text: Selina Vickers was appointed to 'oversee and direct compliance' with the MOU.
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC, p. 2

axioms.text: The AAC required co-chairs from African American, Native American, Asian/Pacific Islander, and Latino caucuses.
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC, p. 1-2

axioms.text: As of June 2021, only the African American caucus existed.

rule_summary: The MOU explicitly conditions the formation of the AAC on the prior existence of four racial diversity caucuses. The plain language of the agreement makes the creation of these caucuses a prerequisite for any legitimate leadership selection.

case_facts.text: The WVDP installed the AAC's leadership slate during a meeting on June 5, 2021.
At the time of the leadership installation, three of the four required racial caucuses (Latino, AAPI, Native American) had not been formed and did not exist.
The compliance officer, Selina Vickers, circulated a pre-written script on June 2 that dictated the formation process in the absence of these caucuses.
case_facts.citation: Draft Script Email June 2; Selina Script

logic_chain: The governing rule (MOU) required that four distinct racial diversity caucuses form the AAC by selecting representatives.
Fact: Leadership was installed via a scripted meeting on June 5, 2021.
Fact: At that time, 75% of the required racial caucuses did not exist.
Application: Non-existent caucuses cannot select representatives.
Conclusion: By installing leadership without the required prerequisite caucuses in place, the WVDP violated the MOU's core requirement.
violation: The WVDP violated the 2020 MOU by forming the AAC before the required diversity caucuses existed, thereby disenfranchising three minority communities from the right to select their own leadership.

title: PROOF: Script's Detail Proves Deliberate Exclusion of Mandated Caucuses
stakes: The committee's foundational decisions lacked mandated representation from 75% of racial diversity groups.
thesis: The exhaustive detail of the formation script, combined with its admission of missing groups, proves the organizers deliberately and knowingly excluded the required Latino, AAPI, and Native American caucuses.

axioms.text: The MOU required an AAC with members from each diversity group 'selected by their particular caucus.'
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC, p. 2-3

axioms.text: Required groups included African Americans, Native Americans, Asian/Pacific Islanders, and Latinos.
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC, p. 2

axioms.text: Selina Vickers authored the AAC formation script.
Only the African American caucus existed in June 2021.

rule_summary: An action is deliberate when the actor possesses knowledge of the rules, is aware of their non-compliance, and proceeds anyway. The combination of detailed planning and documented knowledge establishes intent.

case_facts.text: The script dictated the meeting's flow, including specific nominators and verbatim speeches.
The script contained a section explicitly acknowledging that the process was 'missing... Latinos, Asian Americans/Pacific Islanders and Native Americans.'
Despite this knowledge, the script designated a specific person for a Latino seat even though no Latino caucus existed to make that selection.

logic_chain: The script's meticulous detail demonstrates a high capacity for planning and awareness of the rules.
The script's text documents the organizers' contemporaneous knowledge that 75% of the required racial caucuses were missing.
The combination of detailed planning and documented knowledge of the violation establishes intent.
They proceeded with the formation, consciously choosing to exclude the missing groups.
Conclusion: The organizers deliberately and knowingly violated the core tenets of the DNC MOU.
violation: The organizers deliberately violated the MOU by forming the AAC while knowingly excluding 75% of required racial caucuses—a calculated act of disenfranchisement proven by their own documents.

title: PROOF: AAC Leadership Selection Was Procedurally Invalid
stakes: The committee's leadership was installed through a secret, pre-arranged process, rendering the election a sham.
thesis: The use of a secret, pre-scripted slate of candidates for the AAC leadership election violated the DNC Charter's requirements for open and equal participation.

axioms.text: The DNC Charter requires 'full, timely and equal opportunities to participate' in selecting officers.
The Democratic Party 'shall be open to all who desire to support the Party.'
Selina Vickers was the DNC-appointed MOU compliance officer.
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC, p. 2

axioms.text: The AAC formation meeting was scheduled for June 5, 2021.

rule_summary: The DNC Charter's 'open party' and 'equal opportunity' clauses forbid the use of secret or predetermined processes for selecting party officers, as such methods preclude genuine participation.

case_facts.text: The formation meeting was executed using a script explicitly marked 'DRAFT SCRIPT - do not share.'
The script dictated specific nominations for leadership positions, including 'Mary Ann nominates Hollis Lewis.'
The 'do not share' instruction demonstrates the organizers' awareness that the process was improper and needed to be concealed from other participants.

logic_chain: The DNC Charter rule requires an open process with equal opportunity to participate.
The facts show the election was conducted using a secret script that predetermined the candidates.
A secret, pre-determined process is, by definition, not open and does not provide equal opportunity.
The instruction to keep the script secret proves a consciousness of guilt regarding this violation.
Conclusion: The leadership selection procedure was procedurally invalid under the DNC Charter.
violation: By using a secret script to dictate a pre-arranged slate of leaders, the organizers violated the DNC Charter's core requirements for open and fair processes. The instruction to conceal the script proves they knew the process was improper.

title: PROOF: Script Author Orchestrated Her Own Appointment
stakes: The person responsible for ensuring fair compliance used her position to install herself in a role with procedural control over the committee.
thesis: Selina Vickers, the MOU compliance officer, violated basic ethical standards by authoring a script that orchestrated her own appointment to the powerful role of Parliamentarian.

axioms.text: The Democratic Party requires officials to conduct themselves in a manner that is 'creditably to the Party.'
Selina Vickers was the lead Challenger who triggered the 2020 MOU and was tasked with compliance.
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC

axioms.text: Vickers authored the AAC formation meeting script.

rule_summary: A party official's duty of fair dealing and ethical conduct prohibits them from using their authority to orchestrate their own appointment to a position of power, as this constitutes a profound conflict of interest.

case_facts.text: The script authored by Vickers contains the line: 'I nominate Selina Vickers for Parliamentarian/Secretary.'
The script immediately follows the nomination with a pre-written endorsement stating there is 'no one else remotely qualified.'
The role of Parliamentarian grants the holder control over meeting procedures, rule interpretations, and the creation of official records.

logic_chain: The governing rule requires officials to act creditably and avoid self-dealing.
The facts show Vickers, the compliance officer, authored the meeting script.
Her script directed her own nomination and included a self-serving endorsement.
The role she secured gave her significant procedural control over the very committee she was supposed to help form fairly.
Conclusion: Vickers used her position to write herself into power, a clear violation of ethical standards.
violation: The lead Challenger and MOU compliance officer used her authority over the formation process to orchestrate her own installation into a key role with procedural control, violating fundamental ethical standards of fair dealing and credited conduct.

title: PROOF: Script Reveals Pre-Planned Strategy to Control Dissent
stakes: The meeting was designed to execute a predetermined outcome and suppress opposition, not foster open participation.
thesis: The formation script contained pre-planned tactics to challenge attendees and manage criticism, proving the event was designed for controlled execution rather than open deliberation as required by the DNC Charter.

axioms.text: DNC Charter mandates 'all meetings... shall be open to the public.'
The AAC was formed under the 2020 MOU to ensure an 'open and transparent process.'
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC

axioms.text: Selina Vickers was appointed to oversee MOU compliance.
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC, p. 2

rule_summary: The principle of an 'open meeting' requires genuine, spontaneous deliberation and prohibits the use of pre-planned control mechanisms designed to suppress dissent and ensure a predetermined outcome.

case_facts.text: The script includes a prepared challenge to question the presence of observers: 'I thought this meeting was solely for co-chairs.'
The script anticipates and preemptively characterizes potential criticism from the Party Chair as a 'scolding.'
The script provides specific response strategies to manage and counter expected opposition during the meeting.

logic_chain: The DNC Charter requires open meetings that allow for authentic deliberation.
The script's text demonstrates a pre-planned strategy to challenge observers and manage dissent.
Anticipating and planning to neutralize opposition is fundamentally at odds with the principle of an open, deliberative process.
These tactics prove the meeting was designed to execute a predetermined outcome, not to foster open participation.
Conclusion: The use of pre-planned strategies to manage dissent violated the DNC Charter's 'open meetings' principle.
violation: The use of prepared tactics to manage participation and pre-characterize criticism demonstrates the meeting was a controlled performance, not an open deliberation, thereby violating the DNC Charter's 'open meetings' principle.

title: PROOF: Undisclosed Conflict of Interest Corrupted Committee Process
stakes: A biased external actor with an undisclosed agenda was brought in to overrule a prior democratic vote.
thesis: AAC leadership subverted a democratic outcome by bringing in an external presider, Larry Taylor, without disclosing his profound conflict of interest as Selina Vickers' political associate and business partner.

axioms.text: The DNC Charter requires 'full, timely and equal opportunities to participate' and requires officials to act creditably.
Larry Taylor is the founder of People for Democratic Party Reform (PDPR).
Selina Vickers serves as PDPR's West Virginia Chair.
Taylor and Vickers co-lead trainings on using procedural rules to 'beat the establishment.'
In August, the AAC democratically voted to reject a set of restrictive rules.
axioms.citation: Gmail - Fwd: General Inquiry, RE: AAC information.pdf, p. 2
axioms.url: /files/Gmail - Fwd: General Inquiry, RE: AAC information.pdf

rule_summary: Fair and open proceedings require impartial presiding officers. Intentionally concealing a presiding officer's conflict of interest—especially a close political and business association with a key actor—is a material deception that invalidates the proceedings.

case_facts.text: After the democratic rejection of their rules, leadership brought in Larry Taylor to preside over a subsequent meeting to force the issue.
case_facts.citation: Gmail - Re: Updated agenda and information about presiding officer.pdf, p. 1
case_facts.url: /files/Gmail - Re: Updated agenda and information about presiding officer.pdf

case_facts.text: Taylor's extensive political and business ties to Selina Vickers (the PDPR connection) were not disclosed to the committee members.
A dissenting member left the meeting in protest, explicitly citing the 'clear ties between Ms. Vickers and Mr. Taylor' as evidence of a rigged process.
case_facts.citation: Gmail - Re: Updated agenda and information about presiding officer.pdf, p. 3
case_facts.url: /files/Gmail - Re: Updated agenda and information about presiding officer.pdf

logic_chain: The committee first blocked restrictive rules through a valid democratic vote.
To overcome this, leadership brought in an external actor, Larry Taylor, under the guise of impartiality.
Fact: Taylor was Vickers' close political associate and the founder of her activist organization, PDPR.
Application: This constitutes a severe, undisclosed conflict of interest.
Conclusion: They brought in a biased 'ringer' to force through their previously rejected agenda, subverting the democratic will of the committee.
violation: Using an external actor with a severe, undisclosed conflict of interest to officiate a meeting and overturn a prior democratic vote is a gross violation of ethical standards and fair process, invalidating the proceedings.

title: PROOF: DNC Official Violated MOU by Advising Strategy Against Dissenting Members
stakes: The DNC official tasked with supervising a fair process instead corrupted it by advising one faction on how to defeat another.
thesis: DNC Rules Committee member Harold Ickes violated his duty of impartial supervision under the MOU by advising a non-voting appointee on specific tactics to 'outvote' and neutralize elected minority members.

axioms.text: The MOU guaranteed an 'open and transparent process' with 'full, timely, and equal opportunity.'
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC, p. 1

axioms.text: The RBC's role was strictly limited to 'supervision and technical assistance.'
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC, p. 1-2

axioms.text: Harold Ickes was a DNC Rules & Bylaws Committee member during the MOU period.
Selina Vickers was appointed Parliamentarian, a non-voting position.
Seth Sturm and Mari were elected caucus co-chairs with full voting rights.

rule_summary: An official tasked with 'supervision and technical assistance' for an open process has an affirmative duty of neutrality. Advising one faction on political strategy to defeat another exceeds this authority and constitutes a breach of that duty.

case_facts.text: AAC Co-Chair Mary Ann Claytor provided a written account stating it was 'disturbing to hear Harold admit he advised Selina to 'outvote' Seth, Mari, and others.'
case_facts.citation: Email from Mary Ann Claytor, Sept. 23, 2021

logic_chain: The governing rule (MOU) mandated Ickes' role as a neutral supervisor providing only 'technical assistance.'
The facts show Ickes provided strategic political advice to one faction on how to defeat another.
This action directly contradicts the duty of neutrality and exceeds the scope of 'technical assistance.'
This intervention actively undermined the 'open process' and 'full participation' the MOU was designed to protect.
Conclusion: The DNC's designated supervisor corrupted the very process he was assigned to oversee.
violation: DNC official Harold Ickes violated the MOU and DNC Charter by providing strategic advice to neutralize elected members, thereby exceeding his supervisory role, breaching his duty of neutrality, and corrupting the democratic process.

title: PROOF: Coordinated Smear Campaign Against Dissenting AAC Members
stakes: Elected minority leaders were neutralized through a campaign of character assassination and public harassment.
thesis: AAC leadership and their allies executed a coordinated smear campaign to discredit and silence minority caucus leaders through covertly scripted attacks, public smears, and vicious rumors.

axioms.text: The Democratic Party requires officials to conduct themselves in a manner that is 'creditably to the Party.'
Harold Ickes, a DNC official, advised Selina Vickers to 'outvote' the dissenters.
axioms.citation: Email from Mary Ann Claytor, Sept. 23, 2021

axioms.text: Seth Sturm was the elected co-chair of the Indigenous Caucus.

rule_summary: A coordinated campaign of personal attacks, smears, and harassment against fellow party members for the purpose of silencing dissent is a violation of the DNC Charter's requirement for creditable and ethical conduct.

case_facts.text: Selina Vickers authored and distributed attack scripts with the explicit instruction: 'DO NOT FORWARD THIS EMAIL,' thereby concealing her authorship.
case_facts.citation: Selina asking a Senior Caucus member to attack Seth Sturm.pdf, p. 5
case_facts.url: /files/Selina asking a Senior Caucus member to attack Seth Sturm.pdf

case_facts.text: A dissenting co-chair accused Vickers of spreading 'a vicious rumor that I am dangerous' to undermine his credibility.
case_facts.citation: Gmail - Re: Updated agenda and information about presiding officer.pdf, p. 3
case_facts.url: /files/Gmail - Re: Updated agenda and information about presiding officer.pdf

case_facts.text: An ally of leadership initiated a multi-day social media campaign publicly branding the dissenter a 'toxic bully and saboteur.'

logic_chain: The DNC Charter requires ethical conduct from party officials.
The facts show a multi-pronged attack on dissenting members: covert scripts, vicious personal rumors, and overt public smears.
These actions were not political debate; they were a coordinated campaign of character assassination.
The secrecy involved (e.g., 'DO NOT FORWARD') demonstrates a consciousness of guilt and unethical intent.
Conclusion: This coordinated smear campaign constituted discreditable conduct designed to silence elected minority members, violating the Charter.
violation: The coordinated campaign of covert scripts, public smears, and procedural manipulation against dissenting members was a violation of the DNC Charter's ethical conduct requirements and fair participation mandate.

title: PROOF: AAC Leadership Nullified a Valid Vote to Exclude Minority Caucus Chairs
stakes: The democratic will of the committee was overturned by fiat, disenfranchising the Indigenous and Black caucus chairs from key subcommittees.
thesis: AAC leadership violated democratic principles and the MOU by unilaterally nullifying a valid committee vote and using the invalid proceedings to exclude minority caucus chairs from subcommittee seats.

axioms.text: The MOU's purpose was to ensure 'full participation... with particular concern for minority groups.'
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC, p. 1

axioms.text: Seth Sturm was the elected Indigenous Caucus co-chair.
Mary Ann Claytor was the elected Black Caucus co-chair.
The AAC had formed Planning and Bylaws subcommittees to conduct its work.

rule_summary: Unilaterally nullifying the outcome of a valid democratic vote and using that nullification to exclude mandated minority representatives from participation is a direct violation of any 'full participation' mandate.

case_facts.text: The committee first voted for inclusive, volunteer-based subcommittees, but leadership unilaterally declared the system would be 'by appointment only.'
case_facts.citation: Gmail - Re: General Inquiry, RE: AAC information.pdf, p. 2, 3
case_facts.url: /files/Gmail - Re: General Inquiry, RE: AAC information.pdf

case_facts.text: Following this nullification, leadership denied both the Indigenous and Black caucus chairs seats on the key subcommittees.
case_facts.citation: Gmail - Fwd: Planning & Bylaws Committees.pdf, p. 1

case_facts.text: Leadership then passed a 'Resolution Affirming Support' for themselves in a meeting that the WVDP Appeals Board later ruled was invalid for violating bylaw notice requirements.
case_facts.citation: Resolution of the Board of Appeals, Nov. 29, 2021; 08.17.2021 Resolution Affirming Support.pdf, p. 1

logic_chain: The committee established an inclusive, volunteer-based system via a democratic vote.
Leadership nullified this vote by fiat, imposing an exclusive appointment-only system.
They used this illegitimate system to exclude the chairs of the Indigenous and Black caucuses from key work.
This pattern of exclusion systematically violated the MOU's mandate for full participation of minority groups.
Conclusion: This nullification of a valid vote was a pretext to consolidate power and exclude dissenting minority voices.
violation: AAC leadership violated the MOU by nullifying a democratic decision and then using procedurally invalid meetings to exclude minority caucus chairs, thereby defeating the MOU's core purpose of ensuring minority participation.

title: PROOF: Leadership Deliberately Mislabeled Bylaws to Circumvent Notice Requirements
stakes: Members were denied their statutory right to a 30-day notice period for bylaw amendments, preventing meaningful review and debate.
thesis: Selina Vickers, an expert in procedural rules, deliberately mislabeled substantive bylaw amendments as 'procedural rules' to circumvent the mandatory 30-day notice requirement and ram through changes.

axioms.text: Vickers publicly teaches activists 'How to use rules, procedures and bylaws to beat the establishment.'
WVDP Bylaws require 30 days written notice for any and all amendments.
axioms.citation: WVDP Bylaws, Article XI, Section A

axioms.text: Rules that grant or strip organizational authority are bylaws by definition, not procedural rules.
Larry Taylor founded PDPR, where Vickers serves as the West Virginia Chair.

rule_summary: Deliberately mislabeling a substantive bylaw as a 'procedural rule' to evade mandatory notice periods is a fraudulent act. The actor's documented expertise in procedural manipulation serves as powerful evidence of intent.

case_facts.text: Proposed 'Rule 13' and 'Rule 14' granted Co-Chairs sweeping authority to act between meetings and to appoint/remove subcommittee members—powers characteristic of bylaws.
The document containing these substantive rules was titled 'temporary procedural rules' and circulated less than 24 hours before the meeting.
A committee member recognized the deception during the meeting, stating on the record: 'it's not a procedural rule for handling this meeting.'
After the initial attempt failed, the rules were passed at a subsequent meeting presided over by Vickers' PDPR colleague, Larry Taylor.

logic_chain: The governing rule (WVDP Bylaws) requires a 30-day notice for bylaw amendments.
The facts show that substantive bylaws (granting sweeping authority) were presented as 'procedural rules' with less than 24 hours' notice.
Vickers' own expertise, documented in her PDPR training, proves she understood the distinction and the notice requirements.
This mislabeling was therefore a deliberate act to circumvent the 30-day notice period.
Conclusion: This was a calculated scheme to pass substantive changes without proper notice, rendering the adopted rules void.
violation: Leadership violated WVDP Bylaws by deliberately mislabeling substantive bylaw amendments as 'procedural rules' to circumvent the 30-day notice requirement. The responsible party's expertise in such tactics proves this was an intentional act of deception. Rules adopted through this deception are void.

title: PROOF: PAC Treasurer's Signature Was Forged on Financial Reports
umbrella_category: A New Day PAC Campaign Finance Violations
stakes: Multiple sworn financial disclosure reports, intended to provide public transparency, were filed with the state under a forged signature.
thesis: After its treasurer resigned citing 'ethical concerns,' A New Day PAC knowingly filed subsequent financial reports bearing her forged signature, a criminal act under state law.

axioms.text: West Virginia law requires campaign finance reports to be signed under oath by the committee's treasurer.
Knowingly filing a false report is a criminal offense, constituting false swearing.
Kim Felix served as the registered treasurer for A New Day PAC until her formal resignation.
axioms.citation: A New Day PAC registration records

rule_summary: Only the active, duly-appointed treasurer of a political action committee has the legal authority to sign and swear to the accuracy of its financial disclosure reports. The use of any other person's signature, particularly a former treasurer's, constitutes forgery and false swearing.

case_facts.text: On July 5, 2023, Treasurer Kim Felix formally resigned from the PAC, citing 'ethical concerns' as her reason for departure.
On July 15, 2023, *after* her resignation, the PAC filed its Q2 2023 report, which contained the signature of Kim Felix.
case_facts.citation: A New Day PAC Q2 2023 Filing

case_facts.text: In a sworn witness statement, Ms. Felix confirmed she did not sign any reports after her resignation date.

logic_chain: The law requires the treasurer's authentic signature on sworn financial reports.
Fact: The PAC's treasurer, Kim Felix, resigned on July 5, 2023.
Fact: A report filed on July 15, 2023, bears her signature.
Fact: Felix attests under oath that the signature is not hers.
Application: Someone other than the treasurer signed her name to a sworn legal document.
Conclusion: A New Day PAC filed a state financial report containing a forged signature, a criminal violation of WV Code §3-8-5.
violation: A New Day PAC violated West Virginia campaign finance law by filing official reports with a forged treasurer's signature, an act of false swearing that invalidates the filings and undermines the integrity of public disclosure.

title: PROOF: Unreported Financial Activity - The Scholarship Program
umbrella_category: A New Day PAC Campaign Finance Violations
stakes: A PAC operated an entire scholarship program in the shadows, completely concealing its financial activity from required public disclosures.
thesis: A New Day PAC operated a formal scholarship program but failed to report any of the associated expenditures or in-kind contributions, violating state disclosure laws.

axioms.text: State law requires all political committee expenditures to be publicly reported.
Any 'thing of value' received for which payment is not made must be reported as an in-kind contribution.
A New Day PAC was a registered West Virginia political committee subject to these laws.
The PAC had a prior financial relationship with Progressive Democrats for Party Reform (PDPR), having paid them for consulting services.
axioms.citation: A New Day PAC Q4 2022 Filing

rule_summary: Campaign finance law requires absolute transparency. All financial transactions, whether direct expenditures or in-kind contributions, must be reported. The existence of a program necessitates reportable financial activity.

case_facts.text: On August 22, 2023, the PAC sent an email publicly soliciting applications for a scholarship to attend a PDPR training.
The PAC's Q3 2023 financial report, covering the period of the scholarship, shows $0 in expenditures to PDPR or any other training entity.
case_facts.citation: A New Day PAC Q3 2023 Filing

case_facts.text: The same Q3 2023 report shows $0 in in-kind contributions from any source.
case_facts.citation: A New Day PAC Q3 2023 Filing

logic_chain: The law requires all expenditures and in-kind contributions to be reported.
Fact: The PAC publicly operated a scholarship program in Q3 2023.
Application: A scholarship program, by definition, involves either an expenditure (paying for training) or an in-kind contribution (receiving donated training).
Fact: The PAC's sworn Q3 2023 report lists $0 for both expenditures and in-kind contributions.
Conclusion: The PAC's sworn disclosure is materially false, as it completely omits the financial activity of its scholarship program.
violation: A New Day PAC violated campaign finance law by failing to report any financial activity associated with its scholarship program, thereby filing an incomplete and misleading disclosure and denying the public its right to transparency.
potential_remedies: File a corrected report disclosing all scholarship financial activity.
Provide a full public accounting of the program's funding sources and recipients.
Cease all political activities until the committee is in full compliance with state law.
